forumNotes.author: karyonix
forumNotes.content:
I usually use HxD to overwrite 2-byte 55AA at the end of MBR (or the whole MBR sector) with zero.   
Disable the disk device in device manager and re-enable it. And use disk management to initialize the disk agian.   
Disk numbers in HxD are different from disk numbers in disk management. Be careful.   
There are other methods but this is convenient enough for me.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> but I think that only zeroes the first 512 bytes, how would I modify it to zero everything or would another method work better for all zeros or is that even nessesary? The referenced thread actually is about zeroing 51,2**00** bytes, i.e. first 100 sectors. The idea behind it is simple: partitioning utilities ***may*** look for pre-existing data: * in the MBR (first sector) * possibly in the (normally 62) hidden sectors too
formatting utilities ***may*** look for pre-existing data: * in bootsector of the first (and normally only) partition (first few sectors of the partition).
By zeroing out 51,200 bytes, i.e. 100 sectors, we manage in the vast majority of devices (with a geometry of CxHx63) to: * wipe the MBR * wipe the hidden sectors * wipe first 37 sectors of the first partition
Though theoretically 1+62+16 (at most)=79 sectors should be enough, 512\*79=40,448 bytes which is a number that one may not recall easily. Using 512\*100=51,200 is just a way to save the time to do the above multiplication. Wiping with zero any other sector beyond the above "reasonable" number, is normally NOT needed, and it resolves ONLY in: * loss of time waiting for the wiping to complete * unneeded stress induced to the device
There is an exception, as always, which are keys devices "wrongly" formatted under an "unpatched" Vista, that may result in having: [http://www.911cd.net...o...c=21186\&hl=](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21186&hl= "External link") a larger number of hidden sectors (and thus the beginning of first partition "shifted" at 129th sector), do read the given links in the thread, particularly this one: [http://support.micro...om/kb/931760/en](http://support.microsoft.com/kb/931760/en "External link") (please note how the above may be connected with the "other" problem you are currently having): [http://www.boot-land...?...ic=9104\&hl=](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=9104&hl= "External link") and compare with this: [http://www.msfn.org/...u...63.html\&hl=](http://www.msfn.org/board/usb-booting-issues-t119963.html&hl= "External link") ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
**zoso** ,  
if I may, you are concentrating on the details and are losing the "general" view, and jumping all by yourself to conclusions UNFOUNDED on what has been said.  

You need to start and understand the basics before.  

OF COURSE the data on your internal hard disk has NOTHING to do with the topic at hand. (the partitioning/formatting of ANOTHER drive)  

We are are talking of pre-existing data ON THE SAME device that is to be re-partitioned/formatted, which ***may*** be "carried on" by *some* utilties.  

YOU DO NOT NEED TO REPARTITION/FORMAT/WIPE YOUR INTERNAL DRIVE! :wink:   

On the other hand, working on a system with Acronis (or similar apps) installed to it may cause problems, read this:  
[http://www.boot-land...?...=5736\&st=31](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5736&st=31 "External link")  
and following few posts.  

HD hacker (like any other tool aimed at backing up ONLY the MBR and PBR(s)), will ONLY backup the MBR and PBR(s). ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png)  

If you have DriveImageXML made images, you need normally to ONLY backup additionally the MBR, as the DriveImageXML image is a partition image and will ALREADY contain the PBR.  

**BUT** , if you use HD hacker, (which is a very easy and handy application BTW) you must know that it WON'T work properly if instead of the MBR you have on a given drive a boot manager that spans over the MBR and hidden sectors, as it can backup at most 16 sectors (while, as an example, grub4dos grldr.mbr is 18 sectors and the whole "set" of hidden sectors is usually 63).  

Compare with this:  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=6282](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=6282 "External link")  
**AND** links in it.  

And, again ***half*** OT ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png), but not much ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png), and anyway relevant to the "other" topic, read this:  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=5354](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5354 "External link")  

If you are interested in the matter, you will need to take some time to read LOTS of stuff and learn whatever has been already posted/found/suggested/tested, before being able to "fly with your wings", but it isn't at all difficult :cool:, it just needs some time and patience to get the info, and some more time and patience to "digest" them. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png)   

No offence intended, mind you :wink:, I am aware of your current "newbie" status and I do perfectly understand your enthusiasm ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) , but noentheless, before coming up with questions and proposed initiatives, you should do some homework. ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png)  

:wink:  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
So, you are having problems with an encryption program on a USB disk and you think it may be advisable to fiddle with your internal hard disk that is working perfectly? :wink: My personal suggestion: > **IF AIN'T BROKEN DON'T FIX IT** If, for any reason, you ***need*** to re-format/replace/whatever that hard disk, ***THEN*** it may be an occasion (if you have a valid motivation for it) to start fiddling with it's partitions/MBR. Doing potentially dangerous things just for the fun of it is allright, of course, but I would be curious to know what is the fun in wasting a few hours to re-format and re-install somethng that it isn't giving you any problem. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) > which of these options to use for saving everything available to save with the bootsector(s)? or will I need to save one from each partition seperately? thanks You see. ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) * You do not know how many sector(s) is a bootsector (PBR) long. * You do not know whether this length is the same or it is different in different filesystems. * You are not even sure whether each partition has an own bootsector (PBR) or not.

If you answer yourself, searching and reading info, these three questions: * How many sector(s) is a bootsector (PBR) long? * Is this length the same for all filesystems? * Does each partition have a bootsctor (PBR)?
You won't need to ask your original question, as you will already have the answer for it. Homework :cool:: [http://mirror.href.c.../mbr/index.html](http://mirror.href.com/thestarman/asm/mbr/index.html "External link") Solution (which you shouldn't check before having done your homeworks ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png)): ``` hxxp://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8233&st=7 ```
And, once you go for the "backup" are you sure you know how to Restore properly the data you saved? ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) Out of curiosity, and assumed you know both how to backup and restore the bootsectors, WHAT will you use them for? ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) As said, if you already have a backup of the partitions, you ***won't need*** their bootsectors (PBR's).
![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) jaclaz

forumNotes.author: wendy
forumNotes.content:
I wrote a rexx script that writes floppy images, but the mapped boot sectors were somewhat wrong. Specifically, the DDT table was incomplete.  

See zB [http://hobbes.nmsu.e...k/imgcpy10a.zip](http://hobbes.nmsu.edu/download/pub/os2/util/disk/imgcpy10a.zip "External link")  

It's a rexx script and an array of boot sectors, designed to write a variety of floppy diskettes. It gives you some idea on how to read and create a blank floppy disk from the boot sector, based on WinImage sources.  

It would create eg 160K diskettes, suitable for OS/2's "DOS from drive A" facility.
